title.value: The Canadian Open Neuroscience Platform—An open science framework for the neuroscience community
title.justification: This is the title of the paper provided in the user's message.
title.quote: The Canadian Open Neuroscience Platform—An open science framework for the neuroscience community

extractions.description: This paper provides a high-level overview of the Canadian Open Neuroscience Platform (CONP), which aims to facilitate open neuroscience by providing infrastructure, resources, and guidance for sharing research, data, and tools. The platform includes the CONP Portal for data and tool sharing, NeuroLibre for reproducible publication, and various frameworks for data governance and ethics.

type.justification: The paper presents a perspective on the CONP and its contributions to the neuroscience community, rather than conducting original empirical research or developing new theoretical frameworks.
type.quote: In this manuscript, we provide a high-level overview of this multipronged platform and its vision of lowering the barriers to the practice of open neuroscience and yielding the associated benefits for both individual researchers and the wider community.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on the contributions of the CONP to the field of neuroscience.
name.quote: The CONP Portal provides researchers with access to open neuroscience datasets and the capacity to share their own data, as well as obtain an array of analysis tools that can be applied to data either locally, through remote high-performance computing (HPC) resources, or via cloud services.

name.justification: The paper emphasizes the promotion and practice of open science within the neuroscience community.
name.quote: Open science is an umbrella term that covers the open dissemination of data, software, materials, methodologies, manuscripts, and other products of scientific research, making the entire process more transparent, robust, and accessible.

name.value: Presymptomatic Evaluation of Experimental or Novel Treatments for Alzheimer Disease (PREVENT-AD)
name.justification: The paper mentions this dataset as one of the highly accessed datasets in the CONP Portal.
name.quote: One of CONP’s most highly accessed datasets (more than 3,000 total visits), from the Presymptomatic Evaluation of Experimental or Novel Treatments for Alzheimer Disease (PREVENT-AD) cohort, is illustrative of the Portal’s flexibility.

referenced_paper_title.value: Open science datasets from PREVENT-AD, a longitudinal cohort of pre-symptomatic Alzheimer’s disease.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper details the PREVENT-AD dataset that is used within the CONP.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Tremblay-Mercier J, Madjar C, Das S, Pichet Binette A, Dyke SOM, Étienne P, et al. Open science datasets from PREVENT-AD, a longitudinal cohort of pre-symptomatic Alzheimer’s disease. Neuroimage Clin. 2021; 31:102733.

name.justification: The paper mentions this dataset as having been extended and natively hosted through the CONP Portal.
name.quote: Another dataset that serves as an example of the impact the CONP seeks to have in the neuroscience community by having multiple open-neuroscience endeavors under the same roof is the open Calgary Campinas Brain MRI Dataset, which provides high-quality magnetic resonance imaging data of the human brain for a variety of important research applications.

referenced_paper_title.value: An open, multi-vendor, multi-field-strength brain MR dataset and analysis of publicly available skull stripping methods agreement.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper details the Calgary Campinas Brain MRI Dataset that is used within the CONP.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Souza R, Lucena O, Garrafa J, Gobbi D, Saluzzi M, Appenzeller S, et al. An open, multi-vendor, multi-field-strength brain MR dataset and analysis of publicly available skull stripping methods agreement. Neuroimage. 2018; 170:482–494.

name.justification: DataLad is mentioned as a key technology used for dataset management and retrieval through the CONP Portal.
name.quote: Users who wish to include their data in the Portal can choose among multiple pathways, including storage provided by the OSF, Zenodo, or the CONP, or benefit from greater flexibility still in data-hosting location through the combined use of the DataLad distributed data management system and the GitHub open software repository to host the dataset metadata.

referenced_paper_title.value: DataLad: distributed system for joint management of code, data, and their relationship.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides details on DataLad, which is utilized within the CONP.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Halchenko YO, Meyer K, Poldrack B, Solanky DS, Wagner AS, Gors J, et al. DataLad: distributed system for joint management of code, data, and their relationship. J Open Source Softw. 2021; 6:3262.

name.justification: CBRAIN is mentioned as a technology that allows users to run analysis pipelines on a network of HPC clusters through a web-browser interface.
name.quote: The CONP Portal also leverages other open-source technologies such as CBRAIN, which allows users to run analysis pipelines on a network of HPC clusters through a friendly web-browser–based interface.

referenced_paper_title.value: CBRAIN: a web-based, distributed computing platform for collaborative neuroimaging research.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides details on CBRAIN, which is utilized within the CONP.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Sherif T, Rioux P, Rousseau M-E, Kassis N, Beck N, Adalat R, et al. CBRAIN: a web-based, distributed computing platform for collaborative neuroimaging research. Front Neuroinform. 2014; 8:54.

name.justification: LORIS is mentioned as a data and project management system used within the CONP for patient-centric data.
name.quote: LORIS, a web-based, patient-centric, data and project management system capable of hosting longitudinal behavioral, clinical, neuroimaging, and genetic data.

referenced_paper_title.value: The LORIS MyeliNeuroGene rare disease database for natural history studies and clinical trial readiness.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides details on LORIS, which is utilized within the CONP.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Spahr A, Rosli Z, Legault M, Tran LT, Fournier S, Toutounchi H, et al. The LORIS MyeliNeuroGene rare disease database for natural history studies and clinical trial readiness. Orphanet J Rare Dis. 2021; 16:328.

name.justification: Zenodo is mentioned as a storage provider for datasets in the CONP Portal.
name.quote: Users who wish to include their data in the Portal can choose among multiple pathways, including storage provided by the OSF, Zenodo, or the CONP.

referenced_paper_title.value: DATS, the data tag suite to enable discoverability of datasets.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper details the Data Tag Suite (DATS), which is used within Zenodo for dataset discoverability.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Sansone S-A, Gonzalez-Beltran A, Rocca-Serra P, Alter G, Grethe JS, Xu H, et al. DATS, the data tag suite to enable discoverability of datasets. Sci Data. 2017; 4:170059.
